comments.author: aurabarbiedoll93

comments.text:
Careful using ice on burns. Aloe is good, but ice can actually cause 
damage, such as with frostbite, to skin when placed directly on burns.Its 
the same reason why most first aid guides warn against placing any sort of 
ice or frozen substance against the skin directly, and recommend wrapping 
in cloth or something similar. Its one of those things that sounds good but 
in the end is bad. However, aloe is good, but it much be in gel form to be 
most effective. This allows the skin to breath, whereas many aloe creams 
inhibit oxygen flow. ﻿

comments.author: jordan59961

comments.text:
Also, if you have water in your ears, you can pour a little rubbing alcohol 
in. The alcohol will take care of the water. Just carefully pour a little 
from the bottle into the cap, or saturate a cotton swab (Q-tip) or cotton 
ball. From experience: don't do this if you have any cuts in your ears, be 
they the result of a fresh-popped zit, trying to manipulate or scratch the 
water out, or anything else you crazy kids may do to try and relieve the 
annoyance. You may want someone to help you, but if you can put in eye 
drops no problem, this shouldn't cause much fuss.﻿
